scenario:
Tariffs have been a topic of discussion since November, with various announcements including 25% duties on Canadian and Mexican imports, 25% tariffs on all countries set to come in on March 12, and reciprocal tariffs announced last Thursday. Despite the expected impact on prices and inflation, the bond market does not seem to be concerned, with the 10-year rate remaining below 5%. A recent study by the Centre for Economic Policy Research found that tariffs do not boost inflation as they are a short-term headwind on growth. The Financial Times also reached a similar conclusion, stating that tariffs compress company margins but are typically absorbed by firms and their shareholders.

The Cohen & Steers Infrastructure Fund (UTF) is a bond proxy that pays a 7.6% yield and provides instant exposure to 256 strong utility names, including Duke Energy. About 34% of its portfolio is in electric utilities, and it also holds 16% in corporate bonds. The fund trades near par and is a good opportunity to buy when it's near or below its net asset value (NAV). As rates decline, the NAV will gain, making it a smart "rinse-and-repeat" trade on the 10-year.
